title: If you are arrested, in addition to your right to silence can you just relax your body? Not resisting the police, but not helping them either. - Quora

response.answer_text: “If you are arrested, in addition to your right to silence can you just relax your body? Not resisting the police, but not helping them either.” If the police tell you to stand up and you just sit there, or if they stand you up and you let your legs buckle under you, you are doing what is called “passive resistance” — assuming you don’t have a medical condition or injury which prevents you from standing on your own. If they tell you to put your hands behind your back, but you leave your arms hanging limp at your sides, you are resisting — assuming you don’t have a medical condition or injury which prevents you from putting your hands behind your back. So, no. You don’t have the “right to just relax your body.” That is called “resistance” and may result in additional criminal charges against you. War story alert: I was working one night and backed another police officer who was arresting someone for domestic violence. While we were escorting the arrestee out to the squad car (both of us were holding his arms because he had been actively resisting for a bit), he suddenly went limp and started to fall to the ground. The other officer got pulled to the side suddenly and ended up with a severe muscle strain in his back. The arrestee actually said something like, “Gotcha!” while the officer writhed in pain on the ground. When all was said and done, the arrestee ended up with an additional 30 months in prison for the stunt, as it resulted in a significant injury to the officer. The defense attorney tried to claim that the arrestee “had a fainting spell,” but the jury apparently didn’t believe that. In short, Dear Questioner, no. You don’t have a “right” to relax your body. Passive resistance is still “resistance.”

If you are not helping, you are resisting. Chances are, you won't be charged like you would if you fought. However, your lack of cooperation will be noted and will not endear you to the officers. I would suggest not doing this. While they probably won't be abusive, they won't be gentle either. If you get hurt, your non-compliance will be noted and your injuries will be on you, unless you can prove unnecessary roughness, which is a hard sell. Comply and haggle in court.
